ðŸ‘† Europe is finally treating defence as a strategic responsibility. If Europe wants to lead in defence innovation, we need rules that reward speed, excellence and European technological leadership. â—

Yesterday published the Defence Readiness Roadmap with four flagship capability projects, and the new Military Mobility Package are two important steps for Europeâ€™s security and industrial resilience. 

ðŸ‘‰ Excellence must guide European defence policy. Defence funding must follow strategic logic, not political distribution formulas. Europe needs an excellence based approach across its defence technology and industrial ecosystem. The principle should be clear: European first. If Europeans finance our security, European industry should benefit.

ðŸ“Œ Threat levels are not equal. Countries closest to conventional military risk must be prioritised. Protecting the Eastern flank protects the whole Union. This is also what I am driving as Rapporteur for the Defence Readiness Omnibus in the European Parliament.

ðŸ“Œ The European Drone Defence Initiative, the Eastern Flank Watch, the European Air Shield and the European Space Shield must move forward on a clear timeline and contribute directly to NATO capability targets. Credible deterrence cannot wait.

â—Schengen for defence is at the core of fast military mobility. Europe cannot defend itself if troops and equipment are stopped at borders. The new Military Mobility Package proposes two things.

ðŸ‘‰ First, for military transport operations, a border crossing would be possible within 72 hours after the receiving Member State has received a notification. 

ðŸ‘‰ Second, a fast crisis framework for priority military movement across the Union, with single contact points and shared transport capacity, would enable the Council to approve a year-long derogation for military mobility in only 48 hours. This is essential for reinforcing our Eastern flank as the United States reduces its permanent footprint.

Ukraine continues to demonstrate how agility and technological innovation shape the modern battlefield, and Europe must learn from that reality. That is why Europe must scale innovation procurement, support dual use development and improve access to finance, so that our startups and industry can deliver the capabilities needed for credible deterrence and for the defence of our Eastern flank.

 âœ… Insist on doing everything through â€œ#channelsâ€

posts.text:
Security isn't a destination; it's a relentless, high-stakes race. 

In the world of cybersecurity, resting on your laurels is the single greatest risk. 

Believing your current defenses will be sufficient in six months or a year isn't just naive - it's reckless.

Why? Because the bad actors arenâ€™t taking a break. 

They are innovating, automating, and collaborating. 

To stay ahead, we must continuously push the technological boundaries and move the goalpost forward.

But hereâ€™s the real-world dilemma for most companies: this is incredibly difficult. 

You canâ€™t just rip and replace core systems every time a new threat emerges. These implementations have multi-year lifecycles, and business continuity is paramount.

So, whatâ€™s the answer? 

Leave the fantasy of an impenetrable, single-layered perimeter.

Embrace Security in Depth: The Strategy of Layered Defense.

The goal isn't to have every layer be the absolute cutting-edge. 

The goal is to have enough robust, overlapping layers so that when one is bypassed, the next one is waiting.

Think of it like a castle:

- The moat (Firewalls, Fine-Grained Network Segmentation)

- The high walls (Endpoint Detection and Response - EDR)

- The gatekeepers (Multi-Factor Authentication - MFA)

- The guards on the walls (Security Monitoring & SIEM)

- The inner keep (Data Encryption & Access Controls)

An intruder might cross the moat and scale the walls, but they will be detected, slowed, and stopped long before they reach the crown jewels.

Look at the recent wave of ransomware attacks. 

Often, the initial breach isn't a zero-day exploit. 

It's a phishing email that bypasses one layer. 

Without subsequent layers, like strict user permissions, application allow-listing, or segregated backups, that single point of failure leads to a full-scale compromise.

As the legendary security expert Bruce Schneier aptly said:

"Security is a process, not a product."

This process is about building a resilient, layered system. 

Itâ€™s about assuming breaches will happen and designing your defenses to contain the damage.

Your Action Plan:

1. Conduct a Layered Audit: Map your security controls. 

2. Prioritize foundational hygiene: Often, the biggest gains come from perfecting the basics, ie patch management, MFA enforcement, and principle of least privilege.

3. Focus on Detection & Response: Invest in capabilities that help you identify and contain a threat after it has breached your perimeter.

Staying ahead isn't about having the one "unbreakable" system. 

It's about building a dynamic, layered defense that ensures an intruderâ€™s journey is so difficult and noisy that they are either stopped or you find them before they succeed.

#CyberSecurity #DefenseInDepth #CyberResilience #SecurityStrategy #ZeroTrust 

PS Castel Sant'Angelo has had many dramatic security layer changes. From Mausoleum to Papal Fortress to Prison and to Castle. One can literally see these layers of history stacked on top of each other. DS

posts.text:
I'll never forget standing in front of my new Change Management team in 2018. 

I had just taken on the role, managing them alongside my Platform Delivery team, and I asked a seemingly simple question: 

"Have we mapped our internal and external stakeholders?"

"Compliance team," one person added. "Certification team too," said another.

Sure, these teams were crucial. 

Our work was to ensure quality deployments to production for our company's products across a dozen global jurisdictions and countless data centers. 

The list grew. "Well, there are also regulators..." 

Absolutely, they were key stakeholders.

But a critical category was missing.

We had overlooked our primary internal customers: the engineering teams. 

These were the bulk of people actually submitting the change request tickets we reviewed for quality before sending them for approvals. 

We weren't giving our main "customers" sufficient attention, assuming they'd just continue writing tickets as they always had.

This realization was a turning point. 

It got everyone thinking, brainstorming, and reflecting on how to better cater to the sometimes conflicting needs of all our stakeholders.

The result was a simple infographic that clearly explained what we do and, more importantly, why we do it, with the purpose of creating alignment and finally giving all our customers the focus they deserved.

#ChangeManagement #ITIL #ITSM #Compliance #Certification #Engineering
#InternalCustomers #Agile #DevOps #StakeholderManagement #Leadership #ProcessImprovement

The Commission will publish next week its Digital Omnibus - what can we expect: ðŸ’¡

In general, itâ€™s positive that the Commission seems to be following through with its commitment to simplification and is willing to address mistakes. The leaked Digital Omnibus looks like a chance to deliver targeted fixes and is a test of whether we can turn a jungle of rules into a framework that actually supports European innovation, jobs and security.

â˜ï¸ The question is whether the Council and the Parliament will use it to enable European companies to grow, rather than add yet another layer of complexity.

â˜ï¸ Deregulation, as in removing unnecessary, overlapping or confusing obligations is essential for competitiveness, growth and security. But any â€œsimplificationâ€ must not create new uncertainty for those trying to comply.

ðŸ“Œ On the GDPR, clarifying possibilities for data use for AI training with appropriate safeguards is welcome. Reopening the GDPR is a bold move; the real battle will be around Articles 4, 6 and 9. If almost everything continues to be linked to personal data, Europe will struggle to use data at scale to train its own technologies.

ðŸ“Œ On the AI Act Omnibus, the unresolved â€œstop the clockâ€ question has itself become a source of uncertainty. Companies should not be sanctioned for non-compliance with rules that are not technically and legally clear. Next week the Commission needs to provide a clearly defined pause. â—ï¸

ðŸ“Œ One EU-level sandbox is a good idea and should go further, replacing 27 fragmented national approaches. Not aligning sectoral rules with the AI Act is a missed opportunity and goes against the goal of increasing AI uptake and â€œapplying AIâ€.

ðŸ“Œ Data Act consolidation and targeted updates to the other three laws can be useful, but must not become a lifeline for four flawed proposals by simply merging them. Fully repealing all four and using a proper digital fitness check in 2026 may still be the better way.

ðŸ“Œ Single-entry-point incident reporting is positive if also paired with streamlined reporting for businesses and sufficient resources for ENISA.

â˜ï¸ Finally, withdrawing the stalled CSAM proposal would signal seriousness about fixing, not doubling down on, bad ideas. â—ï¸

#KillTheChatControlForGood

Last night's highly anticipated concert by Dubioza Kolektiv in Stockholm was supposed to be a trio, but one of the lads was, quite literally, on a plane from Japan. 

While we missed Nikola, me and Adi decided to go for it anyway.

And what a decision that turned out to be.

For those who don't know them, Dubioza Kolektiv is more than a band; they're a phenomenon. 

Hailing from the #Balkans, they fuse rock, hip-hop, electronica, and reggae into an irresistible sound, all while delivering a powerful message of social activism, unity, and political satire. 

They are the sound of positive resistance.

Their concert at FÃ¥llan was a super-energetic, two-hour explosion of this ethos. 

They mixed new hits with old classics, and the crowd's energy was electric, a true collective experience. 

It was a live demonstration of their own lyrics: 

"Happiness is the only choice, when you don't have any other option."

When our original plan fell through, we chose to make the best of it, and we were rewarded. 

It was a potent reminder for both life and work: Focus on the energy you have, not the obstacles in your way.

Two hours flew by, but the shared, positive vibration is still going.

There's a unique feeling of combined pride and insight that comes from slicing raw data and watching a story emerge. 

Just yesterday, as I wrapped up the workweek with a custom SQL query in BigQuery against our cloud billing data, that familiar feeling hit me. 

It was a simple task, but the reward was immense, uncovering a perspective that wasn't possible through standard billing reports.

This has been a pattern throughout my career. 

My passion for data started back in 2006 at Nokia, armed with QlikView, SAP, and Excel, extrapolating mobile services usage data for the Nordics. 

The most rewarding part wasn't just building the dashboards; it was the weekly meeting with our sales and marketing teams, translating those data points into actionable insights on customer adoption and channel performance.

This thread continued at NetEnt and now at SEB. 

The tools have evolved, from MySQL and Splunk to Kibana and BigQuery, but the mission remains the same: to let quantitative data guide the way to qualified decisions. 

Data is useless if not communicated and acted upon.

As my career has progressed, the time for rolling up my sleeves and deep-diving into the data well has become more limited. 

But the need for this capability has only grown. 

That's why the most fulfilling part of my role now is transferring this passion to my teams. 

It's incredible to see team members, who were only waiting for the chance, light up as they move from assuming to knowing. 

We've built dashboards for uptake, onboarding, and operational performance that truly help us steer the ship.

"Without data, you're just another person with an opinion." - W. Edwards Deming

I'm a firm believer that a data-informed culture isn't just about the tools; it's about curiosity and the relentless pursuit of the 'why' behind the numbers.

#DataDriven #DataAnalytics #BigQuery #BusinessIntelligence #Leadership #ProductManagement #Cloud #DataStorytelling #SEB #SEBTech #SEBCloud

posts.text:
Ten years back, I was heavily involved in problem management at my previous company. 

As a senior integration manager at the time, I knew quite a lot about both how our systems played and, in the case of problem management, didnâ€™t play together, as well as how our external integrations were set up - which were the bread and butter of the company.

We were a brave crew in the virtual problem management team consisting of people with different skills and competencies, but all with a strong desire to make our systems the best they could be.

It was in this crew I first learnt of the five whys method. (Either from Anibal Wainstein or Erik SchÃ¶n, donâ€™t recall who now.). 

Asking "why?" five times for each problem moved us beyond reactive firefighting into the realm of continuous and very deliberate improvements. 

I have kept the method with me ever since, and been using it for both personal and professional â€root cause analysisâ€.

Itâ€™s a technique that feels almost instinctual, but itâ€™s interesting to know it has a proud heritage. 

The Five Whys technique was developed in the 1930s by Sakichi Toyoda, the founder of Toyota Industries. 

It was born on the manufacturing floor, not in a conference room, as a core component of the Toyota Production System. 

Its power lies in its simplicity - by repeatedly asking "why," you peel back the layers of symptoms to reveal the underlying systemic cause, which is often surprisingly far removed from the initial problem.  

Let's take a common scenario: a critical application is experiencing intermittent slowdowns for users.

1. Why is the application responding slowly?

Monitoring shows the database server is experiencing very high CPU utilization.

2. Why is the database server CPU so high?

A specific, long-running query is consuming excessive resources every time it runs.

3. Why is that query running so inefficiently?

The query is performing a full table scan because a critical database index is missing.

4. Why is the necessary database index missing?

The index was dropped during a recent schema deployment script, and the performance impact wasn't caught.

5. Why wasn't the performance impact caught before deployment to production?

Our deployment process lacks a mandatory performance testing step against a production-like dataset in the staging environment.

By asking the five whys, we were no longer just fixing the immediate problem; we were fixing the system.

Itâ€™s a timeless tool because itâ€™s fundamentally about curiosity and refusing to accept the surface-level answers.

#ProblemManagement #RootCauseAnalysis #FiveWhys #ContinuousImprovement #ITSM #ProcessImprovement #ToyotaProductionSystem

posts.text:
The best running mate Iâ€™ve ever had is 12 years old!

They say the side-by-side journey is often more rewarding than the destination. 

Iâ€™ve just experienced the profound truth in that.

For the past three months, my 12-year-old son and I have been on a mission. 

After jointly deciding to sign up for the #Stadium #NightRun #5k on October 26th, we committed to a shared goal. 

Weâ€™ve been hitting the pavement a couple of times a week, building his stamina and our bond.

My son is well trained, with years of karate and a current focus on basketball. 

But running 5k was new territory for him. 

For me, a consistent runner who logs 5-6 miles a week, the challenge wasn't the distance - it was the pacing. 

I committed to adjusting my speed to his condition, and he continued showing up, even when it was raining or otherwise inconvenient.

"If you want to go fast, go alone. If you want to go far, go together." - African Proverb

And go far we did. 

With each run, the next one became easier. 

We werenâ€™t breaking records, but we were building something more important: resilience and our why. 

By the time we stood at the start line today, I had no doubt we would pull it through.

And so we did.

The track was crowded at times, and the forest was pitch black in sections, making it risky to see where to put our feet. 

But side by side, we pressed on. 

We crossed the finish line together in just around 30 minutes.

Itâ€™s always fun to do a new race, and this one was particularly well-arranged with lots of fun activities leading up to the race. 

But today, the greatest fun came from sharing the moments and experiences with my son. 

The post-finish euphoria was a feeling like no other.

"A fatherâ€™s footsteps are the greatest legacy he can leave his children."

As we walked away, still buzzing from the achievement, we started already looking at which race to run together next.

Iâ€™ve always hoped to pass on my passion and love for running to my kids. 

And what better way to do it than through putting it to the ultimate test in a race? 

Itâ€™s more than just health and fitness; itâ€™s about setting a goal, working for it together, and sharing the triumph.

Hereâ€™s to the next starting line with my favorite running mate!

#Fatherhood #Running #Passion #Family #Goals #5k #LifeLessons #Legacy

posts.text:
The true bedrock of a B2B SaaS isn't just a brilliant product - it's the silent, unwavering reliability of the APIs that power it.

My time at NetEnt from 2013 to 2021, a B2B supplier of casino games, was a masterclass in this. 

We provided the API that powered games for giants like Bet365, Unibet, and 888. 

In that world, "playtime" isnâ€™t a metric; it is actual money. 

Every second of downtime had a direct, significant financial impact on our partners.

Our philosophy was simple: standardization, uniformity, and operational excellence. 

We moved gradually from SOAP to REST and championed a "one-size-fits-all" integration model. 

This wasn't about limiting creativity; it was about enabling scale and ensuring stability.

The results spoke for themselves:

- Massive Scale: Our systems seamlessly served over 80,000,000,000 (billion) game transactions annually.

- Triple-9 (>99,9%) Uptime SLA: We committed to and delivered extreme reliability, with a team ethos of "Zero Downtime" (a literal inscription on our mousepads!).

- Proactive Excellence: We didn't just wait for things to break. We actively monitored API usage to help partners optimize and ran outside-in monitoring to catch risks before they became incidents.

This experience cemented my belief that in the connected economy, your API is your product. 

It's the promise you make to your partners. 

If it's fragile, inconsistent, or insecure, the entire business relationship crumbles.

For any B2B SaaS company, investing in a robust, standardized, and secure API infrastructure isn't a technical afterthought - it's the foundation of trust, scalability, and long-term partnership. 

Itâ€™s the invisible engine that allows the entire ecosystem to thrive.

#B2B #SaaS #API #DigitalTransformation #OperationalExcellence #Tech #Integration #Reliability

ðŸ“£ Hereâ€™s my take on the Commissionâ€™s 2026 Work Programme. This is a bureaucratic policy proposal divided up by different directorates with civil servants working in complete silos in the Commission without political leadership actually wanting our companies to succeed! 

There are a lot of new â€œActsâ€ with a lot of potential for overlap, like with the Innovation Act and the Advanced Materials Act? This needs to be fixed before new money flows in the next budget. 

The continued apparent focus on simplification and defence preparedness is good if delivered in practice. Harmonisation we need for our markets. The pushes on Quantum and a refreshed Chips agenda can be steps in the right direction if done correctly. 

â˜ï¸ First, the 28th Regime. This could actually fix a real structural problem whereby EU firms canâ€™t scale easily across borders. But it must be bold, concrete and deliver a truly EU-wide way to operate when it comes to the legal entity, registry, standardization for all companies and NOT propose a Directive that member states can then implement how they want - if they want. 

â˜ï¸ On digital. I am worried about the Digital Fairness Act. We should really put pressure on the Commission to withdraw the whole idea of pushing any new regulation on digital. The priority should be enforcing what we already have and cutting red tape. Any gaps can be fixed with proper enforcement. 

â—ï¸ We should really now focus on enforcement and NOT push new regulation to the agenda. 
Iâ€™m expecting a lot from the digital omnibus. AVMSD should be a simplification exercise as well as a review of the GDPR. The unfortunate CSAM proposal the Commission should finally withdraw completely. â—ï¸

ðŸ‘‰ Our huge problem is that our digital regulation has been done in complete silos. We need a real cross-check on our digital laws, and a one stop shop for companies to understand what they need to comply with and cut, cut, cut unnecessary and overlapping regulation. 

At the same time we need a real digital tax, contributing to the EU budget, applying to  third country companies entering and doing business in our market. 

ðŸ’¶ Finally, on capital markets and Merzâ€™s recent call for a single European stock market. Thatâ€™s the kind of ambition we need - finish CMU on insolvency law, taxation and open European pension funds for cross-border investments - rather than write more rules that fragment the Single Market. This could be better reflected in what the Commission hopes to achieve in an entire year. Draghiâ€™s message on competitiveness might be heard but not understood.

posts.text:
Like many, I was excited to dive into Sahil Bloom's much-praised book, The 5 Types of Wealth. 

Having followed his work (mostly online), I expected a transformative read. 

The book offers a crucial and valuable mindset shift, but I have to be honest: I found the audiobook experience somewhat monotonous. 

Much of the content, while wise, felt like it would be more impactful as a series of concise Instagram infographics or a long-form article.

That said, let's talk about what makes the core idea so compelling.

The book's premise is a powerful antidote to our cultural obsession with financial wealth. 

Bloom argues that we've been playing a game with a broken scoreboard, one that only measures money. 

True, lasting fulfillment comes from building and balancing five distinct types of wealth:

1. Financial Wealth: The traditional measure - money and assets. Bloom stresses it's an enabler, not the end goal.

2. Time Wealth: The freedom to control how you spend your time, which is our most finite resource.

3. Social Wealth: The quality of your relationships and community, which is a key predictor of long-term happiness and health.

4. Mental Wealth: A mindset of curiosity, purpose, and continuous growth.

5. Physical Wealth: Your health and vitality, which is the foundation that allows you to enjoy all other forms of wealth.

The key insight is that these are not separate; they are interconnected. 

Neglecting one (like Social Wealth while chasing Financial Wealth) can make the entire structure unstable.

A few concepts from the book have stuck with me:

- The "Pyrrhic Victory" of Modern Success: You can win the battle (a promotion, a bonus) but lose the war (your health, relationships). This metaphor perfectly captures the danger of a single-minded focus.

- "You're Your Child's Favorite Person for 10 Years": This quote from the book is a gut punch that forces you to reevaluate your priorities and time allocation.

- The "Life Razor": Create a single, identity-defining statement to guide your decisions (e.g., "I am the type of person who..."). It's a simple tool to cut through complexity and stay aligned with your values. 

- Money Buys Happiness, Until It Doesn't: Bloom agrees money reduces burdens and buys happiness up to a point. Beyond that, the returns diminish dramatically, and the mindless chase for more becomes a trap.

It's worth noting that the book has been widely celebrated, which is why I picked it up in the first place. 

Tim Cook, CEO of Apple, called it "a powerful call to action to think deeply about what lights you up".

Is this book worth reading?

Yes, but with managed expectations.

The 5 Types of Wealth framework is genuinely insightful and impactful. It provides a practical and holistic lens through which to view your life and choices. 

For anyone feeling stuck on the hedonic treadmill of "more," this book can be a course correction.

#BookReview #The5TypesOfWealth #SahilBloom #PersonalDevelopment #Wealth

Another day, another major cloud outage, right? ðŸ“‰ 

This morning, a problem in AWS's US-EAST-1 region took down DynamoDB, causing a domino effect for giants like Snapchat, Venmo, and Fortnite.

But here's the punchline: within a few hours, the underlying issue was "fully mitigated," and services steadily recovered. 

Let's put this in perspective. 

These large-scale outages are not a regular occurrence. 

AWS's last major one was in 2021.

For context, that's a remarkable track record for a system supporting roughly a third of the internet. 

As one expert put it, "Itâ€™s amazing that theyâ€™re able to run at the scale they do without more frequent disruptions." 

The reason these events make headlines is precisely because they are rare and their impact is so widespread. 

The real takeaway? 

It's not about if a cloud provider has an outage - it's about how fast they fix it. And today, we saw that speed in action.

It's also a powerful reminder for businesses: the cloud is resilient, but your architecture must be, too. 

Designing for failure across multiple Availability Zones isn't a best practice; it's a business necessity.

#AWS #CloudComputing #TechOutage #DigitalTransformation #Resilience

They put their beliefs into action, making sure their band merchandise is proudly union-made in the USA and using their stage to call out what they see as threats to democracy. 

In a time when many stay silent, they've declared, "I'm not going to shut up" .

posts.text:
Leaders care about HOW decisions are made. 

Managers care about WHERE decisions are made.

In my experience, leaders push down decision-making to where the knowledge and information is abundant. 

Whereas managers delay and prolong decisions to places and committees where there is not necessarily either knowledge or context, but where there is hierarchy.

Iâ€™ve let David Marquetâ€™s philosophy drive much of my own leadership style, where leadership is more about setting the right context, providing the right tools, and giving guidance and support to team members that ultimately make the decisions given the constraints and opportunities at any given time.

This isn't about abdicating responsibility; it's about embracing a more intelligent and agile form of leadership. 

When you push authority to the information, you donâ€™t just get faster, better decisions - you build a more capable, confident, and engaged team.

As Marquet brilliantly puts it: 

"Don't move information to authority, move authority to the information."

This shift changes everything. 

It moves us from a model of "leader-as-decider" to "leader-as-enabler." 

Itâ€™s about creating an environment where people are empowered to think and act in the best interest of the organization.

It makes me wonder: Are we building hierarchies of control, or networks of competence?

#Leadership #Empowerment #DecisionMaking #DavidMarquet #TurnTheShipAround #IntentBasedLeadership #Management #Teamwork

posts.text:
Sometimes I get the question:

"Why is security in the cloud better than on-premise?"

Hereâ€™s the thing. When done right, cloud security can be fundamentally stronger. 

(Key phrase: when done right. You can absolutely create a horrendous security setup in the cloud, often by treating it like a traditional data center.)

So, let's break down the "why." 

Here are a few key differentiators that have convinced me:

1. Microsegmentation & Zero Trust: 

This isn't just a nice-to-have anymore; it's a necessity. In the cloud, implementing granular, identity-aware security policies is native. And when all your infrastructure is defined as code, spinning up a completely isolated environment for Cloud workloads is trivial.

2. Visibility & Compliance: 

Ever lose track of a server tucked away in a closet? In the cloud, that's much harder. Every resource is billable, which means the cloud providers have a built-in incentive to help you see everything. This creates incredible transparency, making asset management, patching, and ensuring compliance far more manageable.

3. World-Class DDoS Protection, Out-of-the-Box: 

The scale is just different. The major Cloud Service Providers (CSPs) have global networks designed to absorb and mitigate the largest DDoS attacks imaginable - at a scale that would overwhelm traditional on-premise vendor appliances, and it's typically a core part of their service.

4. The Power of Shared Fate: 

This goes beyond the "shared responsibility" model. It's in the CSP's direct business interest that you are secure. If you're hacked, it can impact their platform's reputation and stability. Because of this, they invest heavily in proactive threat detection and will often swiftly deal with suspicious activities across all environments, notifying you and guiding you on next steps.

5. IAM, But Less of a Hassle: 

Let's be honest, Identity and Access Management is complex everywhere. But in the cloud, the tools are built from the ground up to support principles of least privilege, just-in-time access, and role assessment. The guardrails and visibility are simply more mature and integrated.

The bottom line? The cloud provides a security model that is more automated, visible, and inherently resilient. 

Itâ€™s not magic, but it is a powerful force multiplier for engineering and security teams.

What would you add to the list? 

#CloudSecurity #ZeroTrust #Cybersecurity #DevSecOps #IAM #DDoS #SharedResponsibility

posts.text:
Listening to the "#Acquired" podcast on the history of #Alphabet brought back a flood of memories from 2008. It was just one year after the #iPhone launch, and the year #Android was announced. I was at #Nokia.

We were still the undisputed leader in mobile, but the cracks were beginning to show. Our frantic efforts to catch up to both Apple and Google were, quite honestly, falling short, but we were not giving up. 

It was in this climate of rising panic that we tied our fortunes to Microsoft, a company that had, until then, been fairly unsuccessful in mobile.

Come Android, with its strong backing from carriers and OEMs, and the marriage of Nokia and Microsoft became a fact. In retrospect, as Vic Gundotra famously stated, â€œTwo turkeys donâ€™t make an eagle.â€

Neither company was eager to change its ways too drastically in the face of eminent danger. 

Microsoft still wanted to collect meagre licenses from OEMs, and Nokia still had tens of product lines with their respective quirks and perks. This made standardisation, focus, and faster time to market an impossibility.

Meanwhile, Google offered carriers and OEMs a free operating system and a revenue share on search traffic. 

The value proposition was undeniable. 

Why would anyone other than Microsoft and Nokia be interested in preserving the status quo?

Fast forward to today: Android is in over 3 billion pockets, twice the number Nokia had at its peak in 2007. Microsoft has long since left the mobile space.

It all looks so clear in retrospect. 

But at the time, I remember all my hard efforts, evangelising the Windows Phone ecosystem on Nokia #Lumia devices. Itâ€™s a fairly unknown story that many of the early Windows Phone apps in Scandinavia came to be thanks to the dedicated, against-the-odds efforts of me and my colleagues at Nokia and Microsoft.

We fought hard. 

It was, however, not enough to reform two titans to successfully face the disruptive forces of Google and Apple. 

A sobering lesson in strategy, partnership, and the power of an open model.

#Nokia #Microsoft #Google #Android #Apple #Mobile #TechHistory #Strategy #Leadership #LessonsLearned #WindowsPhone #Innovation

My first impression of â€œ7 Rules of Powerâ€ by Jeffrey Pfeffer was that it was highly cynical. 

But as I listened, its pragmatic advice grew on me.

Jeffrey Pfeffer argues that power is a tool, and like any tool, its moral weight depends on the user. 

The rules are brutally effective, even if the examples of figures like Trump, Musk, and Bezos aren't personally who I aspire to emulate.

Here are the 7 Rules of Power:

1. Get Out of Your Own Way. (Stop the self-sabotage).

2. Break the Rules. (It's often easier to ask for forgiveness than permission).

3. Appear Powerful. (Confidence is often taken as competence).

4. Build a Powerful Brand. (Craft and control your narrative).

5. Network Relentlessly. (Your network is your net worth).

6. Use Your Power. (It depletes if not exercised).

7. Success Excuses Almost Everything. (The most controversial, yet hard to deny).

My Takeaway: This isn't your regular feel-good leadership book. 

It's a playbook for the real world. 

The rules can feel uncomfortable, but they describe how organizational dynamics oftentimes work. 

As Pfeffer says, 

"Power is a tool. More good people need to be willing to use it."

I recommend it not as a moral compass, but as a necessary dose of strategic reality. 

Itâ€™s given me a lot to think about.

#7RulesOfPower #JeffreyPfeffer #BookReview #Leadership #CareerDevelopment #PowerSkills #Strategy

posts.text:
Having been a great fan of Blade Runner for as long as I can remember, I knew I had to eventually read the book that served as its inspiration. 

Philip K. Dick's â€Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?â€ is the foundational text from which Ridley Scott and his team borrowed a significant amount of themes and plot elements.

I finally read it, and the book stands perfectly well on its own. 

While not as action-packed as the film, it delivers profound suspense while engaging with quintessential questions: 

What defines a human versus an artificial being? 

What value lies in artificial life, be it androids or electric sheep? 

What kind of love, or at least feelings, can one have for artificial life?

Though not overly dense, the book successfully engages the brain to ponder these essential subjects. In the age of AI, these questions are more relevant than ever.

A central theme is the exploration of empathy as the defining characteristic of humanity. 

The plot revolves around bounty hunters using an "empathy test" to distinguish humans from androids. 

However, as the story progresses, this clear distinction begins to blur.

- The Empathy Paradox: The protagonist, Rick Deckard, is tasked with "retiring" androids based on their supposed lack of empathy. Yet, he finds himself developing empathetic feelings for them, while some humans display a shocking lack of it . This forces him to question the very framework he operates within.

- The Blurred Line: Androids in the story are not merely cold machines. They exhibit behaviors that resemble love, grief, and a desire for self-preservation, making them feel less mechanical and more complex. As I reflected, it seems that with a few more generations, they could emulate empathy well enough to be indistinguishable from humans.

- The Reality of Artificiality: The novel constantly interrogates the value of "real" experiences in a world dominated by simulations. People use "mood organs" to artificially generate their feelings , and ownership of real animals is a major status symbol precisely because most people can only afford perfect electric replicas . This creates a society where the authentic is desperately sought after, yet the artificial is seamlessly integrated into daily life.

Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep? is an excellent, thought-provoking read and a must-have on any sci-fi shelf. 

It provides a deep, philosophical foundation that complements the stylistic brilliance of Blade Runner. 

The book challenges us to look beyond the surface and question what truly gives life - whether organic or synthetic - its value.

In today's world, where AI is advancing at a breathtaking pace, Dick's novel is not just a classic of the genre but a crucial mirror held up to our own technological and ethical landscape.

#DoAndroidsDreamOfElectricSheep #BladeRunner #PhilipKDick #ScienceFiction #BookReview

posts.text:
The argument that "if we just stick to Kubernetes and avoid serverless, we won't be locked in" is a common but fundamentally naive oversimplification of cloud vendor lock-in. 

This perspective conflates platform portability with application portability, ignoring the true source of flexibility: your team's talent and your code's architecture.

To be blunt, if you have engineers capable of writing, rewriting, and adapting your code for new hosting environments at will, you are never truly locked in. 

Your flexibility is a function of your human capital and architectural choices. 

If you lack this engineering capability, then your strategic problems run far deeper than a simple Kubernetes vs. serverless debate; you are already vulnerable, regardless of your infrastructure choice.

Let's dissect the serverless lock-in myth. 

When you build a serverless architecture on a major cloud provider (e.g., AWS Lambda, Azure Functions), you are, in most cases, deploying your code to a container-based runtime. 

The key is that the cloud provider manages this container, its scaling, and its networking entirely for you. 

Crucially, the underlying code itself - your business logic - is often not inherently locked to that platform. 

With careful abstraction, you can containerize that same logic and run it on Kubernetes. 

The inverse - extracting a complex, stateful application deeply intertwined with Kubernetes APIs and custom operators to run on a pure serverless platform - is often far more difficult.

This leads to the critical cost-benefit analysis. 

The promise of K8s is standardization and portability, but it comes at a steep price: a massive management overhead for the control plane, nodes, networking, storage, and ingress controllers. 

You are effectively building and maintaining your own "cloud" within a cloud. 

Serverless, by contrast, offloads this immense operational burden to the vendor, allowing your team to focus on delivering features.

The financial equation is stark: running a containerized application on a managed Kubernetes service (like EKS or GKE) can easily be an order of magnitude (10x) more expensive than its serverless equivalent for comparable workloads, primarily due to the cost of reserving always-on compute resources versus paying for precise, millisecond-level execution.

If you have the luxury of having workloads that fit the serverless model (event-driven, stateless, scalable) without functional drawbacks, you should consider yourself lucky. 

Choosing to forgo the immense benefits of serverless in favor of a more expensive, complex, and labor-intensive Kubernetes setup solely to avoid a mitigated form of lock-in is an irrational trade-off. 

True architectural maturity is about making strategic bets that maximize business value, not pursuing a purist - and often illusory - ideal of portability at any cost. 

The most valuable portability is in your code and your team's skills, not in your choice of infra.

#k8s #faas

posts.text:
Like many, Iâ€™ve found this year to be an emotional rollercoaster, professionally and personally. 

The constant barrage of conflicting narratives, twisted facts, and blatant misinformation can be intellectually draining and deeply concerning. 

It was in this context that I picked up General Michael V. Haydenâ€™s 2018 book, "Assault on Intelligence: American National Security in an Age of Lies."

While written during the first half of the first Trump term, reading it now feels less like revisiting history and more like reading an urgent, clarifying memo about the present moment. 

Hayden, former director of both the CIA and NSA, is no partisan bomb-thrower. 

He is a career intelligence professional who served under both Republican and Democratic presidents. 

His central thesis is as straightforward as it is alarming: the very concept of objective, knowable truth is under sustained attack, and this erosion is the single greatest threat to security and democratic integrity of the Western world.

The book masterfully outlines how the modern intelligence community works - its processes, its ethos of speaking truth to power, and its inherent uncertainties. 

Hayden then contrasts this world of evidenced-based analysis with what he terms the "post-truth" environment, where feelings often outweigh facts and where the authorities of institutions are deliberately undermined.

My takeaways:

1. The Professional Value of Truth: 

Hayden argues that truth isn't a political opinion; it's a professional necessity. 

In our businesses, we rely on accurate data, rational market analysis, and reliable communication to make sound decisions. 

This book is a powerful reminder of what happens when those foundations are intentionally weakened.

2. Institutional Integrity Matters: 

The assault Hayden describes isn't just on individuals, but on institutions themselves - the press, the courts, and the intelligence community. 

This resonates deeply in the corporate world. 

Our companies rely on trust in their brand, their products, and their leadership. 

Undermining that trust has severe, long-term consequences.

Assault on Intelligence is not a comfortable read, but it is a necessary one. 

It is a compelling, expertly argued defense of reason and expertise from a man who has spent his life in the intelligence community. 

For professionals navigating a world increasingly saturated with misinformation, Haydenâ€™s book provides both a critical warning and a measured dose of long-term optimism.

It also reminded me that upholding a commitment to truth isnâ€™t just a moral choice; itâ€™s a professional imperative.

#BookReview #NationalSecurity #Intelligence #MichaelHayden #Truth #PostTruth #Strategy #CriticalThinking

posts.text:
There are probably a few things in the world as fun as sharing oneâ€™s favourite movies, music, games etc with oneâ€™s offspring. 

Iâ€™ve been most lucky in getting my 12 year old son to embrace some of my loves for entertainment categories as diverse as Star Wars, James Bond, Simpsons and South Park. More recently we watched The Tron Legacy together.

This is truly one of the classics. The eternal fight between light and dark, acceptance and dominance, David and Goliath. 

It also comes with many learnings and insights weaved together within all the digital action.

Beyond the incredible visuals and soundtrack, the film sparked a fantastic conversation with my son about what happens when technology escapes human control, and what it means to be â€realâ€ and â€aliveâ€. 

Itâ€™s a story about a son stepping into the vast digital universe his father created, not to simply inherit it, but to understand it, challenge it, and ultimately redefine it on his own terms.

It struck me how much this mirrors our roles as leaders and mentors, whether in parenting or in business. 

We aren't just passing down a static "manual" of what we know. 

We're providing a framework, a "Grid" if you will, and then empowering the next generation to innovate, question, and improve upon it. 

Our goal and challenge is to create environments where they can find their own voice and write their own code.

The real magic isn't just in them embracing our old loves; it's in the new dialogues and shared understandings that emerge from them.

#Parenting #Leadership #Legacy #Mentorship #TronLegacy #CompanyCulture

posts.text:
Ever feel that irrational FOMO when a salesperson hints at what your competitors are doing?

There's a strange phenomenon in business: a huge FOMO for new trends that can make otherwise rational people fairly irrational. 

This is especially true when itâ€™s delivered by a salesperson hinting, however subtly, at what your competitors might be up to.

I find it funny and telling. 

When we hear about the obvious strategic mistakes our competitors are making, our reaction isnâ€™t usually smug satisfaction. 

Instead, we get stressed. 

We think, "What if there's something I don't know? What if this seemingly irrational choice is actually a genius move I'm missing?"

But the truth is, what appears to be a bad strategic choice normally is just that: a bad strategic choice.

The best way to deal with that anxiety-inducing sales pitch is to see it for what it is: a live case study. 

Learn from someone elseâ€™s expensive mistakes as they happen. 

Itâ€™s normally a much cheaper way to gain strategic clarity.

The strongest strategy is built on your own first principles, not on the fear of being left behind.

#Strategy #Leadership #BusinessStrategy #DecisionMaking #FOMO #Sales

posts.text:
A number of years ago I met with David JP Phillips while working at NetEnt. 

He was working with our senior management and as an up and coming manager I got the chance to spend 15 mins with David to sharpen my presentation skills. 

Rarely has a person that I interacted so shortly with, had such a lasting impact on me as he did all these years ago. 

He asked me to present something and afterwards he analysed the presentation and gave me pointers on what to work with. 

I got out, prepared a bit and got back in. 

His pointers helped immensely already there and my presentation was immediately much better. 

I keep his pointers in my head still today whenever Iâ€™m presenting something. 

Therefore itâ€™s been an incredibly fun experience reading his book â€High on Lifeâ€. 

Hereâ€™s what it taught me about the six substances that are essential for living a meaningful and fulfilling life.

Davidâ€™s core idea is that we can consciously influence our own neurochemistry to boost our performance, wellbeing, and happiness. 

These six substances are natural, potent, and available to everyone.

ðŸŽ¯ Dopamine: The Reward Chemical
- Motivation, focus, and the feeling of pleasure after achieving a goal. Itâ€™s the driver of our reward-seeking behaviour.
- Break large goals into small, manageable tasks and celebrate completing each one.

ðŸ˜Š Serotonin: The Mood Stabilizer
- Regulating mood, feelings of well-being, happiness, and self-confidence. It gives you a sense of pride and significance.
- Practice gratitude - reflect on your past achievements. Getting sunlight and spending time in nature are also powerful triggers.

â¤ï¸ Oxytocin: The Love & Trust Hormone
- Social bonding, building trust, deepening relationships, and reducing stress. Itâ€™s the foundation for human connection.
- Give someone a genuine compliment, hug a loved one, or practice acts of kindness.

ðŸƒâ€â™‚ï¸ Endorphins: The Pain-Killing Chemical
- Stress relief, pain suppression, and generating feelings of euphoria (the "runner's high"). Itâ€™s the bodyâ€™s natural mask for pain.
- Laughter is the easiest way. So is vigorous exercise.

ðŸ’ª Testosterone: The Confidence Hormone
- Building confidence, fostering a sense of strength and well-being, and increasing competitiveness (in both men and women).
- Winning (even small wins), setting and achieving goals, and strength training.

ðŸ§˜â€â™‚ï¸ Cortisol: The Stress Chemical
- This is the stress and alert hormone. In small, short bursts it's crucial for survival, but chronic high levels are harmful.
- The key is to reduce and control it through meditation, deep breathing, laughter, and getting enough sleep.

The powerful lesson is that we are not passive victims of our brain chemistry. We have the agency to actively design our days and interactions to generate the positive substances naturally and manage the negative ones, leading to a more engaged, motivated, and fulfilling life.

#personaldevelopment #selfleadership #hormones #highonlife

Stress Isnâ€™t a Baton. Stop Passing It On.

Now listening to David JP Phillips "High on Life" and one realisation in particular hit me hard: 

>> Managers hold the throttle on team stress.

Deliberately or unknowingly putting your team under constant pressure isnâ€™t about "high performance" - itâ€™s in fact a disservice to them AND you.  

Iâ€™ve from time to time been on the receiving end. 

My rule? Rarely carry a managerâ€™s stress to my team. 

If it leaks? Time-box it. Never normalize it.

Science backs this up:

1ï¸âƒ£ Stress is contagious (Harvard Business Review). Cortisol spikes cascade through teams.  

2ï¸âƒ£ Chronic stress shrinks brain (Yale), killing focus & creativity.  

3ï¸âƒ£ Psychological safety != pressure (Googleâ€™s Project Aristotle). Fear stifles growth.  

How I fight the cycle:

âœ… Name it: Call out stress sources transparently.  

âœ… Buffer up: Absorb pressure from above; filter demands.  

âœ… Model recovery: Take breaks. Encourage time off. No martyrdom.  

Leaders! Your stress management isnâ€™t just self-care - itâ€™s also team care!

Finished Greg McKeownâ€™s sequel to â€œEssentialismâ€.

His book â€œEffortless" sets out to prove that sustainable success isnâ€™t about pushing harder - itâ€™s about working smarter.

Here are its key points:  

1. Pair Essential with Enjoyable

â€œThe effortless state is incompatible with resentment. Make the essential things easy by making them enjoyable.â€ 

â†’ Mix essential tasks with joy. Brainstorm on walks. Listen to podcasts while doing admin. Listen to your favourite music while housecleaning. Combine whatever makes it lighter and easier to finish up your â€œchoresâ€.

2. Start with "Minimum Viable Action"

â€œA journey of a thousand miles begins with a single step.â€ - Lao Tzu

â†’ Ask: â€œWhatâ€™s the tiniest step I can take right now?â€ Open the doc. Draft one sentence. Progress â‰  perfection.

3. Timebox to Prevent Overcomplication

"Complexity is procrastination in disguise."

â†’ Set boundaries for any effort. Set a lower and an upper time limit for any task big or small. Constraints create clarity and conserve energy.

4. Build "Done for Tomorrow" Systems

"Do it once to benefit forever.â€

â†’ Automate, create templates, systematize. Document processes. Batch similar tasks. Invest minutes today to save hours tomorrow.

In the modern workplace, â€œEffortlessâ€ is your toolkit for impact without exhaustion. 

Less friction = more flow.  

â†’ My takeaways:

- Deliberately timeboxing work 
- Starting tasks Iâ€™d rather avoid with micro-actions 

#Effortless #Productivity #TimeManagement #Focus #GregMcKeown #WorkSmart #Timeboxing #SelfLeadership

Yesterday, I took my kids (12 and 14) to Kokpunkten in VÃ¤sterÃ¥s - an indoor water slide paradise. 

Half a dozen slides, from gentle glides to vertical drops, packed with a wonderfully diverse crowd: pre-teens, families, and even retirees chasing adrenaline.  

Iâ€™ve always seen myself as a moderate thrill-seeker - never the first to back down, but rarely the most extreme. 

Yet as I near 45, something has shifted. 

For the first time, I didnâ€™t feel compelled to match my kids slide-for-slide. 

After a particularly startling ride? 

Iâ€™d sit the next one out. No guilt, no FOMO. Just quiet appreciation for the pause.  

Was it age? Hard-bought experience? 

Probably both. And honestly? It felt like growth.

I still rode every slide (yes, even the "oh-god-why" ones, once!). 

But watching my kids fly ahead while I caught my breath, I realized: 

Knowing your limits isnâ€™t weakness; itâ€™s clarity.

I was proud to keep pace most of the time - and even prouder watching seniors tackle those same slides with grit and grins.  

As Teddy Roosevelt once said: 

"Comparison is the thief of joy."

Yesterday wasnâ€™t about keeping up. 

It was about showing up - for the laughs, the shared moments, and the humility to step back when needed. And that, to me, is the real adventure.  

Takeaway:

Energy fades. 

Courage evolves. 

But curiosity? Thatâ€™s ageless. 

Hereâ€™s to embracing the ride - on your terms!

#Parenting #LifeLong #Adventure #GrowthMindset

posts.text:
Yesterday, I revisited a place I hadn't seen in at least 25 years: Storvadsbadet.

A small beach less than a kilometre from Old Uppsala's royal mounds and historic church, nestled on the semi-natural shore of the FyrisÃ¥n river.

This quite unassuming spot was my summer sanctuary throughout my teens. 

Without the means for vacations abroad, this was my Saint Tropez, my Playa del InglÃ©s â€“ just a 20-minute bike ride away.

Here, I truly learned to swim in the river's dark waters. Here, my father dazzled with dives my sister and I desperately tried to copy.

Returning yesterday, with my wife, kids, and parents beside me, unlocked a flood of positive memories. 

The place felt timeless: the parking lot, the grass-covered slopes, the red sand, and the FyrisÃ¥n's familiar murkiness â€“ all unchanged. 

We arrived early, finding space before the sun drew crowds. Swimming with my son, I was instantly transported.

As if by magic, my 45 years dissolved. I was 14 again.

Swimming upstream, then down, just as I used to. Memories surged back: a childhood woven with equal parts difficulties, opportunities, love, sadness, and topped off with hard work, and fierce determination to forge ahead.

That swim wasn't just exercise; it was a conversation with my younger self. And the most profound moment? 

Seeing my son catch up, then racing him back to shore. 

Pride washed over me â€“ not just in him, but in the enduring legacy of simple places and shared experiences.

â€œWe do not remember days, we remember moments.â€ â€“ Cesare Pavese

The Takeaway:

Reconnecting with our roots, especially the humble ones that shaped us, is powerful. It reminds us where resilience, joy, and core values were forged. 

Sharing those places with the next generation? 

Thatâ€™s where the past truly comes alive â€“ and where we see how far weâ€™ve swum. ðŸŠâ€â™‚ï¸

#Nostalgia #Family #Resilience #PersonalGrowth #Swimming #Uppsala #Memories #Roots #Legacy

P.S. 1st image: me and my sister back in the 90s in the Storvadsbadet parking lot, 2nd image: me and my son yesterday in roughly the same spot, 3rd image: an image of Storvadsbadet from yesterday.

posts.text:
Itâ€™s funny how people who donâ€™t know you sometimes will assume your life has been linear and predetermined. 

Many see my fitness routine today and imagine Iâ€™ve always been a runner and gym enthusiast. 

When I reveal this habit is barely a decade old - starting in 2011 - theyâ€™re often startled.  

Back then, my late twenties looked very different: endless work trips, constant snacks, zero exercise, and a pack-a-day smoking habit. Air miles piled up; my health did not.  

Then came the catalyst: marriage and children. 

I asked myself: What kind of father did I want to be? One struggling to keep up? Or one matching my kidsâ€™ energy? I chose the latter.  

But resolve didnâ€™t make it easy. 

Starting was brutal. 

I was the awkward newcomer in the gym, fumbling while everyone else seemed â€œborn there.â€ I felt out of place, but I persisted.  

"We are what we repeatedly do. Excellence, then, is not an act, but a habit." -  Aristotle

And slowly, the habits stuck. I began with 2-3 days a week, honoring the routine. The more I ran and trained, the easier it became. 

Results compounded. As progress showed - a faster mile, heavier weights, more energy - my motivation snowballed.  

Today? I run nearly daily and hit the gym 2-3 times weekly. 

Iâ€™m now the guy who looks like he was â€œborn thereâ€ to the new person fiddling with equipment. And yes - I still (mostly!) outpace my teenagers ðŸ˜‰.  

Why share this?  

Because transformation is possible for anyone. 

I went from sedentary smoker to dedicated athlete in my 30s. 

Not through genetics or luck, but consistency and willpower.  

"Small habits donâ€™t add up. They compound." - James Clear

Your "before" doesnâ€™t define your "after." 

Whether itâ€™s fitness, career shifts, or personal growth - change begins when you decide your "why" is stronger than your comfort zone.

Hereâ€™s to embracing the awkward beginnings, trusting the process, and proving that reinvention isnâ€™t just possible - itâ€™s life changing.  

#GrowthMindset #Transformation #FitnessJourney #Resilience #PersonalDevelopment #Fatherhood #Consistency #LinkedInMotivation

P.S. Image to the left from 2010. Image to the right from the other night me trying out the lightning in a new gym, as one does. D.S.

posts.text:
"Your calendar is full again? No worries, you can do the actual work tonight."  

Sound familiar? This mantra of modern work culture isnâ€™t a badge of honor - itâ€™s a recipe for burnout and stagnation. ðŸš¨

Working now in the middle of Swedish â€industrial vacationâ€, makes me reflect how packed my calendar normally is and why the current pace and room for reflection canâ€™t be normal modus operandi? 

The Paradox:
Some stress about having "air" in our calendars, yet glorify back-to-back meetings. 

Some call days "for collaboration" and nights "for execution." 

But if every minute is spoken for - whether youâ€™re a CEO or a developer - when does the actual thinking happen?

Letâ€™s break this down with science:

1ï¸âƒ£  Reflection & Deep Work:
â€When do you get time to reflect on the work youâ€™re assigned?"

Cognitive science shows that reflection consolidates learning and improves decision-making (Harvard Business Review). 

Constant context-switching between meetings shatters focus, leaving no space for synthesis. 

Cal Newportâ€™s research on "Deep Work" proves that uninterrupted blocks are non-negotiable for high-value output.  

2ï¸âƒ£  Improvement & Efficiency:
"When do you identify improvements to make work better?"

Continuous improvement requires deliberate pause. 

As Peter Drucker said, "Follow effective action with quiet reflection. From the quiet reflection will come even more effective action."

Without white space, we default to autopilot - repeating inefficiencies simply because thereâ€™s no time to question them.  

3ï¸âƒ£  Creativity & Innovation:
â€When do you make mind-leaps for breakthrough solutions?"

Insight doesnâ€™t strike in a Teams call. 

Neuroscience reveals that â€aha!" moments often arise during downtime (Default Mode Network research). 

Archimedes had his bathtub; you need calendar margins. Forcing "out-of-the-box" thinking in a boxed-in schedule is futile.  

The Hard Truth:
A packed calendar isnâ€™t productivity - itâ€™s performative busyness. 

Meetings are tools, not the work itself.

If your role requires strategy, creation, or problem-solving (hint: most do), empty space isnâ€™t luxury; itâ€™s infrastructure.  

The Fix?
ðŸ”¹ Ruthlessly defend focus blocks (even 60 mins!).  
ðŸ”¹ Normalize declining meeting with unclear agendas & outcomes.  
ðŸ”¹ Measure output, not occupancy.

Final Thoughts:

As Jason Fried (Basecamp) puts it: â€Work doesnâ€™t happen at work. Meetings, interruptions, and distractions do.â€

If we want better solutions, happier teams, and sustainable performance - we must reclaim the space to think.  

Your move: How will you carve out "air time" this week?  

#Productivity #DeepWork #TimeManagement #Leadership #Innovation #WorkCulture #MentalHealth #Focus

posts.text:
Recently returned from an amazing week in Mallorca â€“ Spain never disappoints, and weâ€™ll be back soon! â˜€ï¸ 

But one experience at Palma de Mallorca Airport (PMI) - operated by Aena, left us stressed and frustrated, highlighting a clear opportunity for improvement.  

The Issue:

On departure day, we arrived early, only to find no automated check-in or baggage drop counters. 

All passengers were funneled into manual check-in lines. 

Despite 5 counters eventually opening, inefficiencies compounded:  

- Staff handled complex items (e.g., a sword!) by involving multiple counters, halting the entire queue.  

- Basic check-in (confirming passengers, printing boarding passes and luggage tags) took >5 minutes per group â€“ a task that takes <5 min on automated counters such as those at Arlanda. 

- After a 1+ hour queue, and then security (thankfully smooth) left us sprinting to the gate during final boarding.  

The Cost:

This inefficiency didnâ€™t just stress passengers â€“ it cost the airport revenue.

We had zero time to shop, dine, or relax. 

Multiply that by hundreds of passengers daily, and the lost opportunity is significant.  

The Solution?

- Automate routine tasks:
Self-service kiosks + baggage drops for standard check-ins free up staff.  

- Dedicated counters:
Handle special items/complex cases separately without disrupting flow.  

- Training:
Empower staff to resolve issues swiftly without gridlocking operations.  

Why It Matters:

Efficiency isnâ€™t just about convenience â€“ itâ€™s economic. 

When airports streamline processes:  

âœ… Passengers spend more on retail/food.  

âœ… Stress drops, improving brand loyalty.  

âœ… Airlines face fewer delays.  

Investing in modern systems and automation pays for itself. 

Palma, we love you â€“ but letâ€™s make the farewell as warm as the welcome! âœˆï¸  

#TravelTech #Automation #AirportExperience #CustomerExperience #Aviation #Innovation #Mallorca #Travel

Yesterday, Oasis kicked off their highly anticipated reunion tour, and the news space overflowed with Gallagher brother drama. But one take truly surprised me.  

During a Swedish radio segment, rather than diving straight into whether Liam and Noel would survive the tour without parting ways for another 16 years, the hosts started by explaining who Oasis even were - and what they meant for Britpop and modern music.

Iâ€™m a longtime Jim Collins fan (â€Good to Greatâ€ and â€Built to Lastâ€ are true classics!). 

Another of his classics, now updated, â€Beyond Entrepreneurship 2.0â€ delivers the deep research, actionable frameworks, and inspirational tone one would expect. 

That said, much of the core material felt like a refinement of his established principles rather than groundbreaking new territory. 

If youâ€™re deeply familiar with his work, some sections will feel repetitive.  

However, the power of Collins lies in timeless truths, not novelty.

Here are my key takeaways:  

1. Level 5 Leadership is Non-Negotiable:
The pinnacle of leadership combines fierce resolve with profound humility. 

Level 5 leaders build greatness through others, not for themselves.  

â€Level 5 leaders channel their ego needs away from themselves and into the larger goal of building a great company."

2. The "BHAG" (Big Hairy Audacious Goal) is Your North Star:
A clear, daring, long-term goal galvanizes the entire organization beyond incrementalism. Itâ€™s not just strategy; itâ€™s a unifying cause.

"A BHAG is clear and compelling, serves as a unifying focal point of effort, and acts as a clear catalyst for team spirit.â€

3. Culture > Strategy (The "Smell of the Place"):
Your culture isn't posters on a wall; itâ€™s the lived behaviors and values reinforced daily. Great cultures attract and retain exceptional people who thrive.  

â€Culture is not just about having fun. Itâ€™s about disciplined people engaging in disciplined thought and taking disciplined action."

4. The Genius of the "AND":
Reject false trade-offs. Truly great companies pursue seemingly contradictory goals simultaneously (e.g., stability AND innovation, purpose AND profit, freedom AND responsibility). 

"Embrace both extremes... not as forces to balance, but as forces to harness."

5. Clock Building, Not Time Telling:
Focus relentlessly on building a system (the "clock") that generates great results long after any single leader or hit product is gone. Build for endurance.  

"Build an organization that can endure and adapt, rather than just riding on a single great idea or charismatic leader."

6. The 20 Mile March:
Consistent, disciplined progress - achieving ambitious but predictable goals year after year - builds resilience and outperforms erratic bursts of effort.  

"Sustainable performance requires consistency through good times and bad."  

While Beyond Entrepreneurship 2.0 might not surprise Collins veterans, it remains an exceptionally valuable blueprint for leaders at any stage. 

Its strength lies in distilling decades of research into practical principles for building visionary, values-driven, and resilient companies. 

If you're new to Collins, this is a phenomenal starting point. 

If you're a seasoned reader, itâ€™s a powerful refresher and refinement of enduring truths.  

#JimCollins #BeyondEntrepreneurship #Leadership #CompanyCulture #BusinessStrategy #BookReview #BHAG

I have an admission to make. 

For about 14 years â€“ since our kids were born â€“ getting through a physical book felt like an impossible feat. 

My focus rightly shifted, and while audiobooks helped me hang on to my love of reading, holding a hard copy remained elusive. 

As the kids are turning into teenagers, I've finally found slivers of time to return to the tangible joy of paper pages. 

These physical books I now select with particular passion, knowing I'll be taking notes, underlining ideas, and looking up references.

One of these special, chosen hardcovers is Gregor Hohpeâ€˜s "Cloud Strategy: A Decision-Based Approach to Successful Cloud Migration".

And I can confidently say: 

This is the book I wish everyone engaged in a cloud transformation would read (ideally prior to starting one).

Forget dry technical manuals or vendor hype sheets. Hohpe cuts through the noise with laser focus. 

This book is an eye-opener, firmly grounded in first principles and centered on asking the crucial questions rather than blindly prescribing this or that framework. 

The author expertly peels back the layers underneath the buzzwords and hype cycles that so often derail cloud initiatives. 

He reminds us that successful cloud adoption is fundamentally a strategic, organisational, and leadership challenge â€“ far more than just some technical problems to be solved. 

If you feel your cloud strategy or migration is drifting, hitting roadblocks, or lacking clear direction, investing in a few copies of this book and starting a book circle might be the wisest course of action.

After reading Hohpe's clear, principled, and decision-focused guidance, you'll know better how to cut through the confusion and concentrate on the key priorities and choices that lead to real success. 

After all, itâ€™s not just about going to the cloud; itâ€™s about succeeding once you're there by making the right decisions along the way.

Had a fantastic session last week with our Summer Tech trainees at SEB! ðŸŒŸ 

I walked them through our cloud journey and explained how we empower developers with managed public cloud environments. 

One brilliant question stood out:  

"How are cloud service providers fundamentally different from what regular companies can build internally?"

I shared my perspective then, but later discovered an even sharper answer in Gregor Hohpeâ€™s â€Cloud Strategyâ€. 

Hereâ€™s the essence:  

Why On-Premises â‰  Cloud: 5 Key Differences

1ï¸âƒ£ Scale: Hyperscalers (like Google/AWS/Azure) operate 100â€“1000x larger data centers than most collocation facilities and definitely far larger than own data centers. On-prem canâ€™t match their elastic capacity for burst workloads.  

2ï¸âƒ£ Hardware: Clouds use custom-designed infrastructure; on-prem relies on off-the-shelf gear.

3ï¸âƒ£ Diversity: Corporate data centers are often "kitchen sinks" of legacy tech; clouds are homogeneous and standardized.  

4ï¸âƒ£ Bandwidth: Hyperscalers sit on internet backbones and lay thousands of kilometres of subsea fibre-optic cables; on-prem battles latency (20â€“30ms hops).  

5ï¸âƒ£ Global Reach: Clouds deliver low-latency access worldwide; on-prem is typically region-locked.

To these five differences, one could add rate of innovation at CSPs due to both scale of operations (billions of users) and scale of both employed and associated talent (in hundreds of thousands and millions individuals), deep integration between various layers in the CSP service offering etc. 

âš ï¸ The Big Takeaway:

Itâ€™s easy to be fooled by surface similarities. 

However, on-prem and cloud operate in radically different contexts. 

Abstraction layers that ignore this often become costly illusions.

Weâ€™ve all heard the dream: 

â€Go cloud-agnostic! Portability! Freedom! Avoid vendor lock-in!â€

But after years in the trenches, Iâ€™ve seen this sales pitch crumble under real-world complexity. 

Hereâ€™s why the â€œagnosticâ€ promise often backfires - and how to do multicloud right:

âŒ The Myth of Magic Portability  

Vendor tools promising seamless cloud portability sound great - until you realize:  

- They play favorites (not all clouds are supported equally).  

- Feature parity is rare (youâ€™ll miss out on CSP-native innovations).  

- Youâ€™re stuck with the lowest common denominator of features across clouds.  

ðŸš« The Illusion of Team Autonomy  

â€œLet every team pick their cloud!â€ sounds flexible - until you face:  

- Policy/security/compliance hell: Reinventing governance per cloud.  

- Wasted effort: Years spent maturing one cloud environment donâ€™t magically make the effort much smaller when adding 2â€“3 more.  

- Fragmented skills: Platform engineers now juggle 3â€“4 cloud systems (+ on-prem!), diluting mastery.  

âœ… The Pragmatic Path: Strategic Multicloud  

Multicloud can work - if youâ€™re disciplined:  

1. Choose clouds for their strengths and only place workloads that make both technical and business sense in each.

2. Govern fiercely: No rogue team choices. Standardize where it matters (IAM, networking, compliance).  

3. Invest in deep expertise: You canâ€™t leverage a cloudâ€™s full potential without understanding its DNA.  

4. Accept reality: Some duplication is inevitable - optimize for outcomes, not theoretical portability.  

ðŸŽ¯ The Bottom Line  

â€œCloud agnosticâ€ often means â€œcloud mediocre.â€

True multicloud success isnâ€™t about forcing sameness - itâ€™s about intentionally leveraging difference. 

Master each cloudâ€™s depth, align with business goals, and govern with rigor. 

Only then do you reap real benefits.

I gather we all know people who have problems prioritising, be that at work or in their lives in general.

Many tend to think that if they manage to cram yet another thing to do into their already packed schedules, there will be more benefits down the line. 

They couldnâ€™t be more wrong! 

Greg McKeownâ€™s â€œEssentialism: The Disciplined Pursuit of Lessâ€ isnâ€™t just another productivity book - itâ€™s a manifesto for reclaiming focus in a world drowning in noise. 

While the core message can feel repetitive at times, its simplicity is its strength: 

ðŸ‘‰ Only once you give yourself permission to stop trying to do it all can you make your highest contribution toward the things that really matter.

As a rehabilitating "yes-sayer," this hit home. 

McKeown reframes productivity not as doing more, but as strategically eliminating the non-essentials to amplify what truly moves the needle.

One quote has stayed with me: 

â€If you donâ€™t prioritize your life, someone else will."

McKeownâ€™s theory aligns with robust research:  

- Decision Fatigue (Baumeister & Tierney, 2011): Our willpower depletes with every choice. Essentialism conserves mental energy for critical decisions.  

- The Paradox of Choice (Schwartz, 2004): More options increase anxiety and reduce satisfaction. Essentialism reduces clutter - mental and physical.  

- Opportunity Cost (Economics 101): Saying "yes" to one thing always means saying "no" to another. Essentialism forces honest trade-off evaluations.  

Itâ€™s important to remember that non-essential tasks arenâ€™t harmless - they actively steal resources from game-changing work.

As McKeown writes: "The way of the Essentialist means living by design, not by default."

If youâ€™re overwhelmed, feel busy but unfulfilled, or struggle with boundaries, this book offers actionable clarity. 

Itâ€™s not about doing less arbitrarily - itâ€™s about making "yes" monumental by mastering "no."

Essentialism is not about how to get more things done; itâ€™s about how to get the right things done. 

#Essentialism #Productivity #Focus #WorkLifeBalance #Leadership #BookReview

I had a great time yesterday presenting at the #googlecloudsummitnordics together with Gergely SzilÃ¡gyi about our cloud journey at SEB, and how we are supporting thousands of developers with thousands of #GCP projects, through some automation magic and some amazing DevOps chops. 

Truth to be told, I don't enjoy the spotlight as much as one could think, but I am not afraid either when it's a topic I care about.

Funny enough, although I spend some thoughts on what to say, when I stand there on stage, at least half of it remains unsaid. 

Just for fun, here is what I was thinking of saying on my 2 slides. 

Slide 1: 

"The slogan for our tech organisation â€Head in the cloud, feet on the groundâ€ is telling for both where we are heading, where we are as well as how we reason about technology. 

We employ 3000 engineers working in all possible tech stacks, from Cobol on mainframe to Golang on Knative. 

Technology has been a natural part of our DNA since start almost 170 years ago and cloud transformation is no different. 

SEBâ€™s cloud journey started back in 2019 with some initial exploration but got really serious when we signed our agreement with Google in 2021. 

It hasnâ€™t always been a straight road, there have been bumps on the way, but we have kept the course steady forward. 

Our initial setup was heavily oriented towards the full stack developers, or if you want early adopters in Geoffrey Moore's technology adoption curve. 

We made sure there were guardrails, controls etc while still leaving development teams to fully manage, develop and operate their piece of our cloud. 

Over time however as more and more teams came into cloud we realized that full stack developers that want to code Java in the morning, have JavaScript for lunch and plan Terraform for dinner, are as rare as unicorns, so we began adding more and more platform engineering layers to fully support all our development teams needs. 

Weâ€™ve been on this journey for a few years now and our adoption numbers among our developer community are telling the story better than anything, while we also see that our engagement numbers have been consistently increasing over time."

For slide 2 notes, see Comments. 

For how the talk actually turned out, watch the on-demand video available on Google Cloud Summit Nordics page. Video in comments. Registration required.

I want to extend a thank you to Google Cloud for showcasing our story, to the audience that seemed interested and engaged throughout and to my partner on stage Gergely SzilÃ¡gyi for great discussions and many laughs while preparing our presentation!

posts.text:
Just wrapped up another excellent Google Cloud Summit Nordics! Here are my top "aha" moments:

1ï¸âƒ£  Lift & Shift is Still Lift & Shi*t

The message was clear: ask any successful cloud migration what strategy they started with, and they'll confirm that going cloud makes sense only if you plan to use the cloud as intended â€“ cloud-native. Trying to replicate on-premise setups directly is still missing the point. See excellent presentations by Terveystalo and Mouseflow.

2ï¸âƒ£  Digital Sovereignty: Pieces Falling In Place, But Gaps Remain
    
All major cloud providers are talking data boundaries, local partnerships, and even bringing some key cloud capabilities back on-premise. While many building blocks are there, key pieces are still missing. Significant progress beyond the current level will likely require additional EU laws and regulations. The intent is visible, but the full solution isn't quite baked yet.

3ï¸âƒ£  AI: Impressive, Contextual... But Where's the Groundbreaking?

The agentic and AI use cases showcased were undeniably impressive, especially regarding contextual reasoning and "intelligence." However, I'm yet to see that truly revolutionary, jaw-dropping use case. Maybe that's just where we are right now? Or perhaps AI has become so seamlessly integrated and "at home" that our expectations have skyrocketed, making it harder to be as impressed as we were a few years ago. Solid progress, but the true paradigm shift feels... pending.

Overall: A really well-organized event (as usual from Google Cloud!). 

Maybe the best part? Catching up with old colleagues I hadn't seen in years â€“ priceless. 

Big thanks to Google for hosting these invaluable gatherings!

P.S. Stay tuned tomorrow for some thoughts on the lightning talk presentation I held together with Gergely SzilÃ¡gyi.

Why Isnâ€™t Sovereign Cloud the DEFAULT for Cloud Providers in Europe?

The cloud giants treat "sovereign cloud" as a specialty product â€“ a compliance add-on for select clients. This is a strategic dodge.  

Every cloud region in Europe should be sovereign-by-design. Period.  

Why isnâ€™t it?

1ï¸âƒ£ Cost Avoidance: Airgapping, EU-based governance, and legal firewalls reduce vendor control and profitability. 

2ï¸âƒ£ Jurisdictional Evasion: Default sovereignty limits extraterritorial reach of U.S. laws â€“ a red line for Washington.  

3ï¸âƒ£ Compliance Theater: "Specialized" sovereign offerings let providers simulate compliance without overhauling core infrastructure.  

I think itâ€™s no more than reasonable to demand: 

- No more "sovereign-as-a-side-project."  

- Every European region: airgapped, EU-governed, legally shielded.

Sovereignty isnâ€™t a "feature."
